issue.title: I didn't know how to contact you about a question that wasn't related to EFCore Power Tools
issue.body:
I know you were working/Help with .Net Core 7 and I ran into an issue with it that I wasn't sure if addressed. I have some SQL tables that use Replication and particularly Merge Transactions. From version 7, I would get the error like 
Server: Msg 334, Level 16, State 1, Line 1
The target table '<Table Name>' of the DML statement
cannot have any enabled triggers if the statement
contains an OUTPUT clause without INTO clause.

I saw things in github like https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/1441 but I never really found anything related to Replication.
I'd like to get going on full testing but I have to revert everything like Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore versions (running 6.04) and its just a pain since its compiled in Azure and the Nugets are created there.

I didn't know if you could point me in the right direct to look or even if I should post an issue. Any info you can provide would be helpful.

[Merge Insert Trigger.txt](https://github.com/ErikEJ/ErikEJ/files/8845575/Merge.Insert.Trigger.txt)

issue.title: "Scaffold" triggers for SQL Server

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
HasTrigger with trigger name only, to make the SQL Server SaveChanges work out of the box.

Closes #28185

issue.title: [Bug] EF7's HasTrigger is not scaffolded for SQL tables with triggers

repository.name: EntityFrameworkCore.Scaffolding.Handlebars
repository.description: Scaffold EF Core models using Handlebars templates.

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Scaffolding the DbContext/models with a SQL table that has a trigger does not generate `HasTrigger()` per a [breaking change](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/ef/core/what-is-new/ef-core-7.0/breaking-changes#sql-server-tables-with-triggers-now-require-special-ef-core-configuration) in EF7. As a result, a DbUpdateException occurs when saving changes that would cause the SQL trigger to fire.

**Expected behavior**
`HasTrigger()` should be generated when needed and changes should save without throwing an exception.

**To Reproduce**
1. Run scaffolding on a SQL table that has a trigger.
2. Observe the DbContext generated does not include `HasTrigger()`.
3. Run code that saves changes to the table with a trigger.
4. An exception is thrown: 
> Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.DbUpdateException: 'Could not save changes because the target table has database triggers. Please configure your entity type accordingly, see https://aka.ms/efcore-docs-sqlserver-save-changes-and-triggers for more information.'

**Additional context**
This was originally reported in https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/28185, which was later closed by https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/pull/28253. This was in the 7.0.0 milestone which I believe means the standard tooling is already handling this, but Handlebars is not. I believe [this area](https://github.com/TrackableEntities/EntityFrameworkCore.Scaffolding.Handlebars/blob/2ddd977384a6781ed24f490f00a9f625fcd59c3d/src/EntityFrameworkCore.Scaffolding.Handlebars/HbsCSharpDbContextGenerator.cs#L409-L415) in HbsCSharpDbContextGenerator.cs corresponds with [this area](https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/blob/8d08146c2cfb1c1ed39231b3ff4260c06350bd6e/src/EFCore.Design/Scaffolding/Internal/CSharpDbContextGenerator.cs#L418-L463) in CSharpDbContextGenerator.cs where the bulk of the changes appear to be (based on the pull request).

I apologize for the lack of a pull request since it feels like I'm about 75% of the way there, but I don't feel like I'm familiar enough with the internal workings of Handlebars to know what else might also need to be updated. Also, the [v7.0.0 version](https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/blob/v7.0.0/src/EFCore.Design/Scaffolding/Internal/CSharpDbContextGenerator.cs) of CSharpDbContextGenerator.cs looks completely different from the file originally included in the pull request, which has me a little puzzled (the current file appears to be generated and doesn't have the `GenerateEntityType()` method where changes were made).
